case_vignette: A man, aged 68 years, with no known history of atopy presents with a 4-month history of an itchy and burning rash on the legs that has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years. He notes that he had dry skin at baseline and did not use emollients, but he did try hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement. Examination revealed ovoid, erythematous, well-marginated plaques on the lower legs and dorsal feet with variable scaling and focal weeping and crusting. There were no nail changes, and the rest of his skin examination was notable only for xerosis.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having an itchy and burning rash on my legs that comes back every winter for the last 3 years.
Do you have any other skin conditions or medical history that may be relevant?
No, I don't have any known history of skin allergies or related issues.
Do you take any medications or have any allergies to medications?
I haven't mentioned any medications or allergies to medications.
Do you have any family history of skin conditions or allergies?
I haven't mentioned any family history of skin conditions or allergies.
Understood. Have you tried using any over-the-counter creams or lotions for the rash?
Yes, I've tried using hydrocortisone 1% cream but it didn't get better.
I see. Have you noticed if the rash gets worse after exposure to cold weather or dry air?
The rash has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years.
**Final Diagnosis:** Atopic Dermatitis
